ALLEGATION:
It was reported that Staff 1 responded to Youth A’s physical aggression act of hitting her on
the side of her head after she was attempting to pick up a phone that he knocked to the floor
from her hand by placing her hand on his chest to create space in between them.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Supervisor 1 at the facility on 4/23/21. He reported that staff placing
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

their hand on a youth to create space is not an approved procedure. He also
reported being told by Staff 1 that “she was upset over Youth A using an open hand
to slap her on the front of her head” because she said she “doesn’t like to be
touched”.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 4/23/21. He described the incident.
I thought we were messing around because she bumped into me and then hit
me on the shoulder with a back hand slap. I hit her back on the shoulder and
she hit me again in the chest with something like a punch. I taped her on the
forehead area before she hit me again in the shoulder.
Youth A reported that Staff 1 told him “I was at the fucking point that I was going to
punch you in the chest”. He also reported that this was the time he walked away. He
reported Youth B and Youth C witnessed the incident. He ended by reporting that he
feels safe at the facility.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility on 4/23/21. He reported being present during
part of the incident described in the allegations. He also reported observing Youth A
hit Staff 1 with a “soft tap of his fist on her shoulder”. He reported that Staff 1 then
“hit Youth A in the chest with her fist”. He denied hearing any inappropriate language
from Staff 1 and ended by reporting that he feels safe at the facility.
I interviewed Youth C at the facility on 4/23/21. He reported being present
throughout the incident described in the allegations. He gave the following
description.
Youth A and I were standing near the window looking out when Staff 1 came
over and asked us what we were doing. She had a phone in her hand and
Youth A told her to get off her phone just before he slapped it out of her hand.
I think he hit her wrist area. She tapped him on the shoulder like a love tap
with an open hand and he smacked her on the forehead with an open hand.
Youth C reported that Staff 1 raised her voice and Youth A “looked like he wanted to
fight her”. He also reported getting between them to keep them from fighting before
Staff 1 went to the office and he walked with Youth A down to his room. He reported
a belief that Staff 1 “handled herself well”. He ended by reporting that he feels safe
at the facility.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 at the facility on 4/23/21. He reported being told about
the incident but not present. He also reported being told by Staff 1 that she was hit
first by Youth A and was pushing him away to keep from being hit again. He
reported that Staff 2 informed him that Staff 1 was “visibly upset” over the incident.
I interviewed Administrator 1 at the facility on 4/23/21. She reported meeting with
Youth A yesterday since she is also his primary therapist. She also reported

receiving “stories that don’t match up” after speaking with Youth A and Staff 1. She
reported that Youth A denies touching or hitting Staff 1 and Staff 1 reported that it
started when Youth A knocked her phone out of her hand.
I interviewed Staff 1 by phone on 5/10/21. She reported never hitting Youth A. She
reported that Youth A knocked her phone out of her hand and when she went to pick
it up, Youth A hit her on the “top of my head”. She reported telling Youth A “don’t
touch me like that”, while standing in front of him. She also reported that at that time,
Youth A struck her in the arm and she “put out my arm straight to put space between
us”. She reported telling him “I don’t like being played like that”. She reported not
being upset until Youth A began to laugh at her and she was in the office area.
I interviewed Staff 2 by phone on 5/11/21. He reported not observing the incident
but speaking to Staff 1 later in the shift. He also reported that she informed him that
Youth A had knocked her phone from her hand and struck her on the head. He
reported that she appeared upset when he first observed her following the incident.
Documents Reviewed:
I reviewed the incident report dated 4/20/21. The incident is described as follows:
When Staff 1 turned around, Youth A knocked the staff's phone out of her
hand. Staff 1 bent down to get her phone when Youth A hit her in the head.
The staff stood up and said, "don't put your hands on me like that", and Youth
A proceeded to hit her again, in the arm this time. Staff 1 then placed her
hand on client near his chest area and created some space between them by
lightly pushing him backwards and reiterated "do not put your hands on me
like that" and then staff walked away.
I reviewed the personnel file for Staff 1 and there was no documentation of
disciplinary action. There was also documentation that Staff 1 had completed all
required training including behavior management techniques including de-escalation
training.
I reviewed the following policy/procedures.
Behavior Management Procedures [05-01]. This policy states that staff are to use
“a variety of de-escalation approaches and activation of client self-control plans”.
Another technique is “Staff members can avoid power struggles by offering options
and stating clearly what the staff will do instead of telling the client what to do”.
Behavior Management Procedures – Recommended Techniques [05-01.1]. This
policy states the following. “Expectations: Use a neutral voice tone and a confident,
yet non-threatening posture to clearly communicate what is expected of a client.
Often, staff can ask clients to describe the expectation which can reduce resistance.”

Behavior Management Procedures – Prohibited Techniques [05-01.2]. This
policy states, “Corporal or physical punishment including hitting” is prohibited.
Crisis Management Procedures [05-02]. This policy states, “Physical management
will only be used after all other less restrictive methods of intervention have been
determined as ineffective”.
I reviewed the facility “Fill in” document. This document states the behaviors of youth
for each shift. On 4/20/21 during the PM shift it is noted, “Youth A was given 2 days
of C1 consequences for striking Staff 1. He appeared very upset.”
I reviewed the safety plan developed for Youth A. This document is dated 5/7/21 and
is titled “Personal Boundary and Safety Plan for Youth A”. Youth A is to avoid
touching peers and staff while staff are to “exercise vigilance and continual
monitoring of Youth A”. Staff are also to use “redirection if Youth A begins to interact
inappropriately with peers”.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(2) At a minimum, the behavior management system shall
include all of the following:
(a) A structured system designed to reward the positive
behavior of individual residents based upon the effort put
forth.
(b) Positive intervention strategies to assist residents in
developing improved problem solving, self-management,
and social skills.
(c) Written guidelines for informally resolving minor
misbehavior.
(d) Written rules of conduct that specify all of the
following:
(i) Expected behavior.
(ii) Acts that are prohibited in the institution.
(iii) The range of interventions that may be
imposed for violation of those rules.
(e) Scheduled training for institution personnel in the
behavior management system.
(f) A provision for resident input into the proper
application of the behavior management system.
(g) A provision for the distribution of behavior management
policies and procedures to residents, parents, and referral
agencies.

ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance as Staff 1 did not use an
appropriate method when attempting to deal with Youth A’s
behavior. Her striking him with her hand is not a method that is
approved by the facility and is not a “positive strategy” in
assisting Youth A to make positive choices in his actions.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
III. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended, upon receipt of acceptable action plan no change made to the
license of this Child Caring Institution.
